data.title: Learn about Dali’s life in Catalonia
data.meta_description: Rent a luxury villa in Spain and delve into the life and works of Salvador Dali in the Dalian triangle in Catalonia.
data.text:
Salvador Dali was one of the leading artists of the twentieth century. This Catalan artist symbolizes surrealism and made a name for himself with his easily-recognised works. Want to know more about the life and works of this Spanish artist? Then these three places are a must for your holiday on the Costa Brava.

Dali Theatre-Museum, Figueres

Our first stop is the town of Figueres, where Salvador Dali was born on 11 May 1904 and is located north of Girona and west of Roses. You can’t miss the Dali Theatre-Museum and it has the painter’s off-the-wall personality written all over it, with giant eggs topping the Galatea tower. It opened in 1974, and the location was not left to chance – Salvador Dali chose to build this museum opposite the church where he was baptised. This was also first place he displayed his work. The museum houses a collection of the painter’s artworks such as the Galatea of the Spheres or his Soft Self-Portrait with Grilled Bacon. You should also know that the Dali Theatre-Museum in Figueres is where Dali’s embalmed body is laid to rest.

Salvador Dali House and Museum in Portlligat

Now a museum, Dali used to live in this house. In fact, it is the only stable address that he is known to have had. He lived there until 1982 when he moved to Pubol castle following the death of his wife, Gala. The extensions added by the painter turned this little fisherman’s house into something of a maze. It features many parts of Dali’s life including his living quarters, workshop, and the grounds. Admire the view over the bay of Portlligat from the garden, then venture inside to discover an intimate interior which reflects the artist’s quirky personality. And there’s a recurrent theme… here too, the towers are topped with eggs!

House and Museum at Gala Dali Castle in Pubol

Next, we head to Pubol, east of Girona. Salvador Dali bought Pubol Castle in 1969. At the time, it was in a pitiful state. Dali and Gala completely renovated it, turning some of the property’s original features into wacky spaces so typical of them. The result is an array of interesting architectural delights such as trompe l’oeil details. This was Dali’s last workshop. He spent two years here before returning to Figueres after a fire at the castle.
